Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).

content.verbatim_text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should avoid broad feedback licenses, limiting them strictly to general comments on product functionality and excluding any Zebracorp IP rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial defensive tactic to protect Zebracorp's core intellectual property. While allowing for the use of general feedback, it prevents a counterparty from gaining unintended rights or licenses to Zebracorp's underlying technology or IP.
content.justification: This provides a specific strategic limitation on the scope of feedback licenses Zebracorp should accept.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its intellectual property by ensuring that feedback clauses do not inadvertently grant broad licenses to its core technology or products.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers providing feedback to Zebracorp should expect that any license granted for their feedback will be narrowly defined, focusing on functional comments rather than broader IP rights.
content.source_insight: This balances the desire to receive feedback with the need to protect proprietary assets.
content.text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: Under any projects where a party likely gives feedback of the other party’s products or services, in particular in cases where the subcontractor gives us feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which we pay for anyway) we should add the following clause: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”
content.plain_text: In projects where feedback is likely, especially from subcontractors on Zebracorp products, Zebracorp should add a clause stating that feedback is optional, can be used by the receiving party at their sole risk without royalties, is provided 'as is', and grants no implied IP license.
content.expert_insight: This provides a comprehensive, pre-approved clause for managing feedback. It protects Zebracorp by ensuring free use of feedback without compensation, disclaiming warranties, and explicitly preventing any unintended IP license grants, which is crucial for maintaining control over its product development.
content.justification: This provides specific contractual language to be used for feedback clauses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp secures the right to use valuable feedback without incurring royalty obligations or granting unintended IP licenses, streamlining its product development process.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers providing feedback to Zebracorp will do so knowing it may be used without compensation, 'as is', and without granting any IP rights to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: This clause is designed to address all the potential ambiguities and risks associated with feedback.
content.text: Under any projects where a party likely gives feedback of the other party’s products or services, in particular in cases where the subcontractor gives us feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which we pay for anyway) we should add the following clause: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”

content.verbatim_text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created. See the guidance: https://www.zebracorp.com/guidance
content.plain_text: If a subcontractor is a competitor, Zebracorp risks 'contamination' from their confidential information, potentially requiring the creation of separate 'clean teams'. Refer to the provided guidance link for more information.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a critical competitive intelligence risk. 'Clean teams' are a sophisticated legal and operational mechanism to manage information flow when dealing with competitors, preventing misuse of confidential information and mitigating antitrust concerns. The referral to external guidance indicates a complex area requiring specialized handling.
content.justification: This provides important contextual information about a specific risk and a potential mitigation strategy.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must be vigilant about 'contamination risk' when engaging competitors, potentially incurring the operational overhead of 'clean teams' to protect itself from legal and competitive issues.
content.implication_supplier: A subcontractor who is also a competitor should be aware that Zebracorp will implement strict measures, such as clean teams, to manage the exchange of confidential information.
content.source_insight: This points to a broader organizational policy or guidance beyond the immediate contract drafting.
content.text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created. See the guidance: https://www.zebracorp.com/guidance

content.verbatim_text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties.
content.plain_text: Residuals mean information of a general nature (including ideas, concepts, know-how, and techniques) in non-tangible form, which can be retained in the unaided human memory by persons who had access to the other party's Confidential Information, and whose acquisition by these employees is merely an enhancement of their personal knowledge, skill, or experience.
content.expert_insight: This definition allows parties to use information retained in employees' memories without explicit documentation, which is particularly relevant in R&D collaborations where 'cleaning out' information from engineers' minds is impractical.
content.text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp contract templates typically list the following four exclusions: i.) information that is in the public domain at the time of disclosure or later becomes part of the public domain through no fault of the receiving party; and ii.) information that was previously known to the receiving party; and iii.) information that is disclosed to the receiving party by a third party who did not obtain such information, directly or indirectly, from the disclosing party; and information that was independently developed by the receiving party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard exclusions from confidential information are: public domain info, previously known info, info from a third party not sourced from the discloser, and independently developed info.

content.verbatim_text: Where requested by the supplier/subcontractor, we should not have an issue with expanding the above list to also include: information that is explicitly approved for release by the disclosing party; and vi.) information that is required to be disclosed by law or court order.

content.verbatim_text: As for point vi.) above, it is customary to specify that the disclosure by law or court order is only allowed if before making such disclosure, the party planning to make such disclosure shall, to the extent permitted by applicable law give the other party a reasonable opportunity to intervene and/or take action to seek confidential handling of such information and reasonably cooperate with the other party, to seek confidential handling of such information.
content.plain_text: Disclosure required by law/court order should be conditioned on the disclosing party providing the other party reasonable prior notice and opportunity to intervene/seek confidential treatment, and cooperating in such efforts.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protective measure to ensure the disclosing party has a chance to protect its information even when legal disclosure is mandated.
content.conditions: When disclosure is required by law or court order.
content.justification: To allow the disclosing party an opportunity to protect its confidential information through intervention or seeking confidential handling.

content.verbatim_text: In such (rare) cases, it is recommended to add the following clause covering the use of this residual information: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”
content.plain_text: Recommended language for a residuals clause defines "Residuals" as general, non-tangible information retained in unaided memory, enhancing personal knowledge, and allows either party to use such residuals for any purpose, explicitly excluding rights to the source or IPR licenses.

content.verbatim_text: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”
content.plain_text: Recommended feedback clause: Parties may provide feedback, which the receiving party can use/incorporate at its own risk, royalty-free, and without compensation. Feedback is "as is," and no IP license is granted by the feedback provider.
content.expert_insight: This clause provides a clear, royalty-free right for Zebracorp to use feedback on its products, while explicitly disclaiming warranties and preventing the feedback provider from claiming IP rights over the feedback itself.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To allow Zebracorp to freely use feedback received on its products without incurring royalties or IP claims, while disclaiming warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can freely use feedback received on its products without incurring royalties or IP claims.
content.implication_supplier: If providing feedback, the supplier grants Zebracorp free, "as is" use rights without IP license.
content.text: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). content.expert_insight: This highlights the severe financial risk associated with confidentiality breaches, emphasizing the importance of strict compliance.

content.plain_text: Zebracorp prefers a broad definition of confidential information, covering all technical or commercial information exchanged, regardless of disclosure method.

content.verbatim_text: A more narrow definition of confidential information would require each document to be labelled with the legend "Confidential", “Proprietary” or similarly in order to for the information to be protected.
content.plain_text: A narrow definition of confidential information typically mandates explicit labeling (e.g., 'Confidential', 'Proprietary') on each document for protection.
content.expert_insight: This 'labeling' requirement can create loopholes if not strictly followed, potentially leaving sensitive information unprotected.

Oral disclosures for which protection is sought must be clearly identified in writing by discloser as information within xx days from disclosure”.

content.expert_insight: This example illustrates the specific administrative steps a narrow definition would impose, highlighting potential compliance challenges.

content.implication_supplier: Illustrates the specific and potentially burdensome requirements of a narrow definition.

content.verbatim_text: This type of a narrow definition can prove to be problematic for us since Zebracorp does not have a requirement to in e.g. include such confidentiality notices in our email communications.

content.verbatim_text: For this reason, we should be careful to accept any such requirement to specifically label or identify which data should be treated in confidence.

content.justification: Zebracorp's current practices (e.g., email communications) do not align with such a requirement, leading to potential operational difficulties and risks of unprotected information.
content.implication_company: Must actively negotiate against or modify any clauses requiring specific labeling of confidential information to avoid operational friction and compliance risks.

content.text: For this reason, we should be careful to accept any such requirement to specifically label or identify which data should be treated in confidence.

content.verbatim_text: The main argument against this narrow definition is that it sets out an administrative requirement that in practice will be routinely ignored by both parties. Having a specific obligation to label all materials including all oral disclosures as confidential is very difficult to adhere to in practice. It is by no means customary within the industry to summarize each discussion with details on items that should be kept in confidence. In fact the parties are likely to rely on being able to discuss matters freely in reliance that an NDA/confidentiality undertaking is in place to protect the confidentiality of the discussions. Removing this type of a requirement ultimately benefits both parties since this requirement may result in confidential information of a party to be inadvertently made public information.
content.plain_text: Arguments against a narrow definition include: it's an administrative burden often ignored, difficult to label all materials and oral disclosures, not industry customary to summarize discussions for confidentiality, parties rely on general NDAs for free discussion, and removing it prevents inadvertent public disclosure of confidential information, benefiting both parties.
content.expert_insight: These points collectively argue for a more practical and less administratively burdensome approach to confidentiality, emphasizing that overly strict requirements can be counterproductive and increase risk.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Provides strong justifications for advocating a broad definition, citing practical difficulties and mutual benefits.
content.implication_supplier: May find these arguments persuasive for adopting a broader, less administratively intensive confidentiality approach.
content.text: The main argument against this narrow definition is that it sets out an administrative requirement that in practice will be routinely ignored by both parties. Having a specific obligation to label all materials including all oral disclosures as confidential is very difficult to adhere to in practice. It is by no means customary within the industry to summarize each discussion with details on items that should be kept in confidence. In fact the parties are likely to rely on being able to discuss matters freely in reliance that an NDA/confidentiality undertaking is in place to protect the confidentiality of the discussions. Removing this type of a requirement ultimately benefits both parties since this requirement may result in confidential information of a party to be inadvertently made public information.

content.plain_text: If a narrow, labeling-based confidentiality definition is unavoidable, Zebracorp should add a clause stating that unmarked information will still be considered confidential unless it's unreasonable to treat it as such.
content.expert_insight: This provides a crucial fallback, mitigating the risk of inadvertent disclosure due to missed labeling, while still acknowledging the primary labeling requirement.
content.conditions: If a narrow definition requiring labeling cannot be negotiated away.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp from unintended loss of confidentiality due to administrative oversight in labeling, while still attempting to accommodate the counterparty's preference.
content.implication_company: Should actively seek to include this protective language if forced to accept a labeling requirement, to minimize risk.
content.implication_supplier: May encounter this proposed language from Zebracorp if a strict labeling requirement is insisted upon.
content.text: In the event this narrow definition cannot be negotiated away we should add the following language after such labelling requirement: “Despite the foregoing, in the case of failure to mark information as confidential or proprietary said information shall be deemed confidential information hereunder unless it is of the type or nature that could not reasonably be expected to be treated as confidential”.

content.verbatim_text: Should the subcontractor categorically reject the foregoing compromise proposal, and should Zebracorp subsequently be forced to accept an obligation to summarize all verbal disclosures into written format, Zebracorp should appoint a single point of contact (a so called “gatekeeper”) to disclose any Zebracorp confidential information under the respective contract, and agree that any and all disclosures and receiving of confidential information may take place only through this nominated contact person. Respectively, this person then bears the responsibility in Zebracorp for ensuring any and all oral disclosures are put into written format as agreed with the subcontractor.
content.plain_text: If a subcontractor rejects the compromise and Zebracorp must summarize verbal disclosures in writing, Zebracorp should appoint a 'gatekeeper' as the sole point of contact for all confidential information exchange, responsible for documenting oral disclosures.
content.expert_insight: This is a high-risk scenario requiring stringent control measures. A gatekeeper centralizes responsibility and minimizes the potential for compliance failures in a demanding environment.
content.conditions: If a subcontractor rejects the compromise proposal and Zebracorp is forced to accept an obligation to summarize all verbal disclosures into written format.
content.justification: Centralizes control and responsibility for a highly burdensome and risky obligation, ensuring compliance and accountability.
content.implication_company: Must establish a formal 'gatekeeper' role with clear responsibilities and authority to manage all confidential information flow and documentation.
content.implication_supplier: Will be required to interact with a single designated 'gatekeeper' for all confidential information exchanges.
content.text: Should the subcontractor categorically reject the foregoing compromise proposal, and should Zebracorp subsequently be forced to accept an obligation to summarize all verbal disclosures into written format, Zebracorp should appoint a single point of contact (a so called “gatekeeper”) to disclose any Zebracorp confidential information under the respective contract, and agree that any and all disclosures and receiving of confidential information may take place only through this nominated contact person. Respectively, this person then bears the responsibility in Zebracorp for ensuring any and all oral disclosures are put into written format as agreed with the subcontractor.

content.verbatim_text: The confidentiality clause typically also defines what is excluded from the definition of confidential information. The exclusions are often relatively consistent and non-contentions. Zebracorp contract templates typically list the following four exclusions: i.) information that is in the public domain at the time of disclosure or later becomes part of the public domain through no fault of the receiving party; and ii.) information that was previously known to the receiving party; and iii.) information that is disclosed to the receiving party by a third party who did not obtain such information, directly or indirectly, from the disclosing party; and information that was independently developed by the receiving party.
content.plain_text: Confidentiality clauses usually define exclusions, which are often consistent. Zebracorp's templates typically exclude: information in the public domain (without receiving party's fault), previously known information, information disclosed by an independent third party, and independently developed information.
content.expert_insight: These standard exclusions are crucial for ensuring that parties are not unduly restricted from using information legitimately acquired or developed outside the confidential relationship.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Understands the standard exclusions from confidentiality and their importance in protecting its ability to use legitimately acquired information.
content.implication_supplier: Understands the standard exclusions from confidentiality, which protect its ability to use legitimately acquired or developed information.
content.text: The confidentiality clause typically also defines what is excluded from the definition of confidential information. The exclusions are often relatively consistent and non-contentions. Zebracorp contract templates typically list the following four exclusions: i.) information that is in the public domain at the time of disclosure or later becomes part of the public domain through no fault of the receiving party; and ii.) information that was previously known to the receiving party; and iii.) information that is disclosed to the receiving party by a third party who did not obtain such information, directly or indirectly, from the disclosing party; and information that was independently developed by the receiving party.

content.verbatim_text: Where requested by the supplier/subcontractor, we should not have an issue with expanding the above list to also include: information that is explicitly approved for release by the disclosing party; and vi.) information that is required to be disclosed by law or court order.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should generally agree to expand the list of exclusions to include information explicitly approved for release or required to be disclosed by law/court order, if requested by the supplier/subcontractor.
content.expert_insight: These additional exclusions are standard and reasonable, providing necessary flexibility for both parties while maintaining core confidentiality protections.
content.conditions: If requested by the supplier/subcontractor.
content.justification: These are common and reasonable exclusions that do not undermine the core intent of confidentiality. Explicitly approved release or legal mandate are legitimate grounds for disclosure.
content.implication_company: Should be prepared to accept these additional exclusions during negotiations.
content.implication_supplier: Can reasonably request these additional exclusions be included in the confidentiality clause.
content.text: Where requested by the supplier/subcontractor, we should not have an issue with expanding the above list to also include: information that is explicitly approved for release by the disclosing party; and vi.) information that is required to be disclosed by law or court order.

content.verbatim_text: As for point vi.) above, it is customary to specify that the disclosure by law or court order is only allowed if before making such disclosure, the party planning to make such disclosure shall, to the extent permitted by applicable law give the other party a reasonable opportunity to intervene and/or take action to seek confidential handling of such information and reasonably cooperate with the other party, to seek confidential handling of such information.
content.plain_text: Regarding legally mandated disclosures, it is customary to require the disclosing party to notify the other party, allow them reasonable opportunity to intervene or seek confidential handling, and cooperate in such efforts, to the extent permitted by law.
content.expert_insight: This 'notice and cooperation' clause is vital for protecting the disclosing party's interests, even when legal disclosure is unavoidable, by allowing them to seek protective orders or confidential treatment.
content.conditions: When including an exclusion for information required to be disclosed by law or court order.
content.justification: Provides a mechanism for the disclosing party to protect its information even when legally compelled to disclose, by involving them in the process of seeking confidential treatment.
content.implication_company: Must ensure this 'notice and cooperation' language is included when accepting a legal disclosure exclusion to protect its information.
content.implication_supplier: Should expect and be prepared to adhere to 'notice and cooperation' requirements if relying on a legal disclosure exclusion.
content.text: As for point vi.) above, it is customary to specify that the disclosure by law or court order is only allowed if before making such disclosure, the party planning to make such disclosure shall, to the extent permitted by applicable law give the other party a reasonable opportunity to intervene and/or take action to seek confidential handling of such information and reasonably cooperate with the other party, to seek confidential handling of such information.

content.plain_text: Zebracorp requires an explicit right to disclose confidential information to its affiliates, subcontractors, external contractors, consultants, advisors, and customers.

content.implication_supplier: Should expect Zebracorp to request this broad right of disclosure to its network of partners and customers.
content.text: Zebracorp must have a specific right to disclose information to its affiliated entities (i.e. entities belonging to the same corporate group) and typically also to its other subcontractors, external contractors, consultants, advisors and customers.

content.verbatim_text: The right to disclose to such third parties is practically always made subject to each of those third parties reasonably having a need to know such information, and subject to such third parties agreeing to be bound to confidentiality in writing to an extent not less stringent than the obligations imposed on the receiving party.
content.plain_text: Disclosure to third parties must always be conditional on their 'need to know' and their written agreement to confidentiality obligations at least as stringent as those imposed on the primary receiving party.
content.expert_insight: These two conditions are non-negotiable safeguards, ensuring that information is only shared with essential personnel and under equivalent protective terms.
content.conditions: When granting or receiving a right to disclose confidential information to third parties.
content.justification: Ensures that information is only shared with relevant parties and that those parties are legally bound by equivalent confidentiality standards, minimizing leakage risk.
content.implication_company: Must implement internal processes to verify 'need to know' and secure written confidentiality agreements from all third parties receiving its confidential information.
content.implication_supplier: Will be required to ensure its third parties meet 'need to know' criteria and sign confidentiality agreements with equivalent stringency.
content.text: The right to disclose to such third parties is practically always made subject to each of those third parties reasonably having a need to know such information, and subject to such third parties agreeing to be bound to confidentiality in writing to an extent not less stringent than the obligations imposed on the receiving party.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp gives this right to the supplier, we should require that such right to disclose is limited to named sub-suppliers of the supplier only. This is particularly important in R&D collaboration where Zebracorp gives out product technical specifications and other sensitive information of our products.
content.plain_text: When Zebracorp grants a supplier the right to disclose confidential information, it should limit this right to only named sub-suppliers, especially in R&D collaborations involving sensitive product technical specifications.
content.expert_insight: This restriction is crucial for maintaining control over highly sensitive intellectual property, preventing broad dissemination through a supplier's extended network.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp grants a supplier the right to disclose Zebracorp's confidential information to third parties.
content.justification: Limits the potential for sensitive Zebracorp information, especially in R&D, to be disseminated beyond a controlled group, reducing risk.
content.implication_company: Must insist on this limitation when granting disclosure rights to suppliers, particularly for R&D projects.
content.implication_supplier: Should expect this limitation on disclosure rights when receiving Zebracorp's confidential information, especially in R&D.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp gives this right to the supplier, we should require that such right to disclose is limited to named sub-suppliers of the supplier only. This is particularly important in R&D collaboration where Zebracorp gives out product technical specifications and other sensitive information of our products.

content.verbatim_text: In any event such right to share confidential information to third parties should be conditional on the receiving party accepting responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use of the confidential information by such third party to the same extent, as if it had been its own unauthorized disclosure or use of information.
content.plain_text: Any right to share confidential information with third parties must be conditional on the primary receiving party accepting full responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use by those third parties, as if it were their own breach.
content.expert_insight: This 'pass-through liability' clause is essential for maintaining accountability, ensuring the primary party remains fully responsible for safeguarding information even when shared downstream.
content.conditions: When allowing a receiving party to share confidential information with its third parties.
content.justification: Ensures accountability remains with the primary receiving party, incentivizing them to properly manage and enforce confidentiality with their third parties.
content.implication_company: Must always include this clause to ensure the primary receiving party bears the ultimate responsibility for its confidential information.
content.implication_supplier: Must be aware that if it shares Zebracorp's confidential information with its third parties, it will be fully liable for any breaches by those third parties.
content.text: In any event such right to share confidential information to third parties should be conditional on the receiving party accepting responsibility for any unauthorized disclosure or use of the confidential information by such third party to the same extent, as if it had been its own unauthorized disclosure or use of information.

content.verbatim_text: The duration of the confidentiality obligations should generally be no less than 5 years from the date of disclosure.
content.plain_text: Confidentiality obligations should generally last for a minimum of 5 years from the date of disclosure.
content.expert_insight: A 5-year term is a common and reasonable baseline for protecting most confidential information, balancing protection with practical limitations.
content.conditions: When defining the duration of confidentiality obligations.
content.justification: Provides a reasonable period for protecting most confidential information, aligning with industry standards for many types of data.
content.implication_company: Should advocate for a minimum 5-year duration for confidentiality obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Should expect confidentiality obligations to last at least 5 years.
content.text: The duration of the confidentiality obligations should generally be no less than 5 years from the date of disclosure.

content.verbatim_text: Shorter time frames should only be accepted if the nature of information to be shared with the supplier/subcontractor is not particularly sensitive.
content.plain_text: Shorter confidentiality durations should only be accepted if the shared information is not highly sensitive.
content.expert_insight: This provides flexibility for less critical information but emphasizes that sensitive data warrants longer protection.
content.conditions: When considering a confidentiality duration shorter than 5 years.
content.justification: Less sensitive information may not require as long a protection period, allowing for negotiation flexibility.
content.implication_company: Should only agree to shorter durations for non-sensitive information, exercising caution.
content.implication_supplier: May be able to negotiate shorter durations for less sensitive information.
content.text: Shorter time frames should only be accepted if the nature of information to be shared with the supplier/subcontractor is not particularly sensitive.

content.verbatim_text: In exceptional cases where Zebracorp discloses especially sensitive information to its suppliers, we may wish to consider including a penalty or liquidated damages clauses which will impose a monetary penalty on the supplier for any breach of the confidentiality undertakings.
content.plain_text: For exceptionally sensitive information shared with suppliers, Zebracorp may consider including penalty or liquidated damages clauses to impose monetary penalties for breaches.
content.expert_insight: Liquidated damages can provide a clearer path to recovery and act as a strong deterrent, especially when actual damages are hard to quantify.
content.conditions: In exceptional cases involving especially sensitive information disclosure to suppliers.
content.justification: Provides a pre-determined remedy and strong deterrent for breaches of highly sensitive information, where actual damages might be difficult to prove.
content.implication_company: May use this as a tool for enhanced protection of critical information, but should weigh the negotiation impact.
content.implication_supplier: Should be aware that Zebracorp might propose such clauses for highly sensitive information, which could be a point of contention.
content.text: In exceptional cases where Zebracorp discloses especially sensitive information to its suppliers, we may wish to consider including a penalty or liquidated damages clauses which will impose a monetary penalty on the supplier for any breach of the confidentiality undertakings.

content.verbatim_text: However, these clauses should never be introduced lightly as we should expect the supplier to balk at such at liquidated damages/penalty provision.
content.plain_text: Penalty or liquidated damages clauses should not be introduced casually, as suppliers are likely to resist them.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the potential for negotiation friction and the need to reserve such clauses for truly exceptional circumstances.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Should be strategic in proposing such clauses, understanding they are likely to be contentious.
content.implication_supplier: Is likely to resist liquidated damages/penalty provisions, so Zebracorp should be prepared for negotiation.
content.text: However, these clauses should never be introduced lightly as we should expect the supplier to balk at such at liquidated damages/penalty provision.

content.verbatim_text: When using this type of a penalty provision, it is important to ensure that the payment of the penalty/liquidated damages does not relieve the supplier from liability for any other damages or release the supplier from its obligation to continue to honour the confidentiality undertakings.
content.plain_text: If a penalty or liquidated damages clause is used, ensure that its payment does not absolve the supplier from liability for other damages or from ongoing confidentiality obligations.
content.expert_insight: This is critical to prevent the penalty from becoming a 'buy-out' clause, ensuring that the supplier remains fully accountable for all harms and future compliance.
content.conditions: When including a penalty or liquidated damages clause.
content.justification: Prevents the penalty from acting as a cap on liability or a release from ongoing obligations, ensuring comprehensive protection and deterrence.
content.implication_company: Must explicitly state that penalty payments do not limit other damages or ongoing obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Should understand that a penalty payment will not relieve it of other liabilities or ongoing confidentiality duties.
content.text: When using this type of a penalty provision, it is important to ensure that the payment of the penalty/liquidated damages does not relieve the supplier from liability for any other damages or release the supplier from its obligation to continue to honour the confidentiality undertakings.

content.verbatim_text: While it would be common to disclaim liability for indirect or consequential damages in most contracts, in NonDisclosure/Confidentiality Agreements, the losses or damages that may occur could be argued to be indirect or consequential. For this reason, such a disclaimer is not commonly used in these type of agreements and we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.
content.plain_text: While disclaiming indirect/consequential damages is common in most contracts, it's not typical in NDAs/Confidentiality Agreements because breaches often lead to such damages. Zebracorp should be very cautious about accepting such exclusions for confidentiality breaches.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a critical distinction: the very nature of confidentiality breaches often results in indirect or consequential harm, making a disclaimer for these types of damages inappropriate and highly detrimental to the injured party.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Must recognize the unique nature of confidentiality breaches and strongly resist exclusions of indirect/consequential damages.
content.implication_supplier: Should understand that Zebracorp will likely reject exclusions for indirect/consequential damages in confidentiality agreements.
content.text: While it would be common to disclaim liability for indirect or consequential damages in most contracts, in NonDisclosure/Confidentiality Agreements, the losses or damages that may occur could be argued to be indirect or consequential. For this reason, such a disclaimer is not commonly used in these type of agreements and we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.

content.verbatim_text: we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should be very careful about accepting clauses that exclude indirect or consequential damages for confidentiality breaches.
content.expert_insight: Accepting such an exclusion could severely limit Zebracorp's ability to recover the full extent of losses from a breach, as many confidentiality-related harms are indirect.
content.conditions: When negotiating confidentiality agreements.
content.justification: Breaches of confidentiality often result in indirect or consequential damages, and excluding them would significantly limit Zebracorp's ability to recover full losses.
content.implication_company: Must actively negotiate against or reject any clauses that exclude indirect or consequential damages for confidentiality breaches.
content.implication_supplier: Should understand that Zebracorp will strongly resist exclusions for indirect or consequential damages in confidentiality agreements.
content.text: we should be very careful to accept the exclusion of indirect or consequential damages for breaches of confidentiality.

content.verbatim_text: Residuals clause in non-disclosure agreements usually gives the parties the right to use such other party’s confidential information which is retained in the employees’ unaided memories in non-tangible form (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by those employees who had access to the other party’s confidential information.
content.plain_text: A residuals clause in NDAs typically grants parties the right to use confidential information retained in employees' unaided memories (non-tangible, without intent to memorize or reference documents).
content.expert_insight: This clause addresses the practical reality that human memory cannot be 'erased,' allowing for the use of general knowledge gained, provided it wasn't intentionally memorized or documented.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Understands the concept and implications of a residuals clause.
content.implication_supplier: Understands the concept and implications of a residuals clause.
content.text: Residuals clause in non-disclosure agreements usually gives the parties the right to use such other party’s confidential information which is retained in the employees’ unaided memories in non-tangible form (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by those employees who had access to the other party’s confidential information.

content.verbatim_text: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services but does not acquire any deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets, Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause when purchasing R&D work if it doesn't gain deep knowledge of the subcontractor's products or trade secrets.
content.expert_insight: Accepting a residuals clause in such a scenario would grant the subcontractor unnecessary rights to Zebracorp's information without reciprocal benefit, potentially exposing Zebracorp's IP.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services without acquiring deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets.
content.justification: Prevents the subcontractor from gaining rights to use Zebracorp's confidential information through the 'unaided memory' provision when there is no genuine reciprocal risk or benefit.
content.implication_company: Must actively reject residuals clauses in these specific R&D scenarios to protect its intellectual property.
content.implication_supplier: Should understand that Zebracorp will likely reject a residuals clause if the engagement doesn't involve deep knowledge transfer of the supplier's IP.
content.text: When Zebracorp purchases R&D work and services but does not acquire any deep knowledge of the subcontractor’s own products and trade secrets, Zebracorp should not agree to a residuals clause.

content.verbatim_text: However, when Zebracorp is genuinely working/collaborating together with a subcontractor in R&D projects, and has the risk of receiving subcontractor’s proprietary sensitive information which may be difficult to “clean out” of the engineers’ memory, the usage of the residuals clause might be beneficial. In such (rare) cases, it is recommended to add the following clause covering the use of this residual information:
content.plain_text: In genuine R&D collaborations where Zebracorp risks receiving sensitive subcontractor proprietary information that's hard to 'clean out' of engineers' memories, a residuals clause might be beneficial. In these rare cases, a specific clause for residual information use is recommended.
content.expert_insight: This acknowledges the practical challenges of knowledge transfer in deep R&D collaboration and provides a mechanism to manage the 'unintended' retention of information.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Understands the specific circumstances where a residuals clause might be advantageous for managing shared sensitive IP.
content.implication_supplier: Understands the specific circumstances where a residuals clause might be advantageous for managing shared sensitive IP.
content.text: However, when Zebracorp is genuinely working/collaborating together with a subcontractor in R&D projects, and has the risk of receiving subcontractor’s proprietary sensitive information which may be difficult to “clean out” of the engineers’ memory, the usage of the residuals clause might be beneficial. In such (rare) cases, it is recommended to add the following clause covering the use of this residual information:

content.verbatim_text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”
content.plain_text: Residuals are non-tangible, general information (ideas, concepts, know-how, techniques) retained in unaided human memory by individuals who accessed the other party's confidential information, provided its acquisition only enhances their personal knowledge/skills. Both parties can use such Residuals, but this right does not include using/disclosing the source or any intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: This definition carefully balances the practical reality of human memory with the need to protect the original source and formal intellectual property, preventing unintended licensing.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: “Residuals” mean information of general nature (including but not limited to ideas, concepts, know-how and techniques) in non-tangible form, which a) may be retained in the unaided human memory (i.e. without reference to any document and without the intent to memorize the information) by persons who have had access to the Confidential Information of the other Party, and b) is of such a nature that the acquisition of it by these employees amounts to no more than an enhancement of the personal knowledge, skill or experience used by them in the exercise of their duties. Either Party shall be free to use for any purpose the Residuals (defined above) resulting from access to or work with other Party’s Confidential Information disclosed hereunder. For the sake of clarity, the right to use Residuals as agreed above does not give the receiving Party the right to use, disclose, publish, or disseminate the source of Residuals, or any license rights under any patents, copyrights or any other intellectual property rights.”

content.verbatim_text: In cases where it is seen as likely that under any (non-disclosure) agreement one party gives feedback to the other party solely relating to such other party’s (i.e. receiving party’s ) products or services, it is recommended to include a feedback clause, which clarifies how the receiving party can use such feedback.
content.plain_text: If it's likely that one party will provide feedback on the other party's products/services, a feedback clause should be included to clarify how the receiving party can use that feedback.
content.expert_insight: A feedback clause prevents disputes over ownership and usage rights of suggestions, which can otherwise become a source of intellectual property conflict.
content.conditions: When it is likely that one party will give feedback to the other party relating to the other party’s products or services.
content.justification: Prevents potential disputes over ownership and usage rights of ideas or suggestions provided as feedback, which could otherwise be claimed as proprietary.
content.implication_company: Should proactively include feedback clauses in agreements where feedback exchange is anticipated.
content.implication_supplier: Should be aware that Zebracorp may propose a feedback clause to clarify usage rights.
content.text: In cases where it is seen as likely that under any (non-disclosure) agreement one party gives feedback to the other party solely relating to such other party’s (i.e. receiving party’s ) products or services, it is recommended to include a feedback clause, which clarifies how the receiving party can use such feedback.

content.verbatim_text: Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).
content.plain_text: Without a clear feedback clause, the party giving feedback might claim its suggestions are proprietary and confidential, leading to potential confidentiality breaches or IPR infringement if used by the receiving party.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the significant legal risks, including IP infringement, that arise from not explicitly addressing feedback in agreements.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Recognizes the legal risks (confidentiality breach, IPR infringement) of using feedback without a clear clause.
content.implication_supplier: Understands the potential for claiming ownership of feedback if no clause exists.
content.text: Without a proper feedback clause it might be possible that the first party to assert that the idea/suggestion forming the feedback is the first party’s proprietary and confidential information and the usage of such feedback would amount to breach of the confidentiality agreement (and potentially also an IPR infringement).

content.verbatim_text: Usually the party requesting a right to use feedback will also request a full-blown license to use such feedback.
content.plain_text: The party seeking to use feedback typically requests a comprehensive license for its use.
content.expert_insight: This sets the expectation for negotiations, indicating that a broad license will likely be sought.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Should anticipate requests for broad feedback licenses.
content.implication_supplier: May seek a broad license for feedback provided.
content.text: Usually the party requesting a right to use feedback will also request a full-blown license to use such feedback.

content.verbatim_text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should reject broad or open feedback licenses, ensuring any accepted license is strictly limited to general comments on product functionality and excludes Zebracorp's intellectual property rights.
content.expert_insight: This protects Zebracorp's core IP, preventing feedback from inadvertently granting rights to its proprietary technology or future product development.
content.conditions: When negotiating feedback clauses.
content.justification: Prevents the inadvertent licensing of Zebracorp's intellectual property rights through feedback, maintaining control over its core assets.
content.implication_company: Must carefully review and narrow the scope of any feedback license to protect its IP.
content.implication_supplier: Should understand that Zebracorp will only grant limited licenses for feedback, specifically excluding its IP.
content.text: However, Zebracorp should not agree to any broad or open licenses but the license to use feedback must be strictly confined to general comments on the functionality of the products in question, and must not include any Zebracorp intellectual property rights.

content.verbatim_text: Under any projects where a party likely gives feedback of the other party’s products or services, in particular in cases where the subcontractor gives us feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which we pay for anyway) we should add the following clause:
content.plain_text: In projects where a party is likely to give feedback on the other's products/services, especially when a subcontractor provides feedback on Zebracorp's products/services (beyond paid-for feedback), Zebracorp should add a specific feedback clause.
content.expert_insight: This proactive measure clarifies usage rights for unsolicited or non-contractual feedback, preventing future disputes.
content.conditions: In projects where a party is likely to give feedback on the other party’s products or services, especially when a subcontractor gives feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which Zebracorp pays).
content.justification: Provides a clear framework for handling feedback, preventing claims of ownership or IPR infringement, particularly for unsolicited feedback.
content.implication_company: Should proactively insert this clause in relevant project agreements to manage feedback effectively.
content.implication_supplier: Should be aware that Zebracorp will likely include this clause to govern feedback provided.
content.text: Under any projects where a party likely gives feedback of the other party’s products or services, in particular in cases where the subcontractor gives us feedback about Zebracorp products or services (other than for which we pay for anyway) we should add the following clause:

content.verbatim_text: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”
content.plain_text: This clause states that parties may provide feedback, and the receiving party can use it in their products/services at their own risk, without royalties or compensation. Feedback is provided 'as is' with no warranties, and no express or implied license is granted by the feedback provider.
content.expert_insight: This clause clearly defines the terms of feedback usage: optional submission, royalty-free use by the recipient at their own risk, and no implied IP transfer, protecting both parties.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Provides a clear framework for receiving and using feedback without incurring royalty obligations or implied IP licenses.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies that any feedback provided is 'as is,' without warranties, and does not grant any license rights.
content.text: “The parties may, but are not obliged to, propose ideas or suggestions to each other relating to the other party’s products and services (“Feedback”). The party receiving Feedback shall be entitled to use and incorporate such Feedback in receiving party’s products/services, at the Feedback receiving party’s sole risk and without any obligation to pay any royalties or other compensation or consideration to the other party for such use/incorporation; provided however that the Feedback is provided “as is” basis without warranties of any kind, and no license, express or implied, is granted by the Feedback giving party to the Feedback receiving party under this clause.”

content.verbatim_text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created.
content.plain_text: If a subcontractor is a competitor, Zebracorp faces a 'contamination risk' from receiving their confidential information, potentially necessitating separate 'clean teams'.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the serious antitrust and intellectual property risks when dealing with competitors, requiring strict internal controls like clean teams to prevent misuse or perceived misuse of information.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Must be aware of and mitigate 'contamination risk' when engaging competitor subcontractors, potentially by implementing 'clean teams'.
content.implication_supplier: Should understand that if it is a competitor, Zebracorp may implement strict measures like 'clean teams' to manage information exchange.
content.text: Please note that where the subcontractor is a competitor of Zebracorp, either in business or product level, Zebracorp may bear the risk of getting “contaminated” by receiving such subcontractor’s confidential information, and therefore separate clean teams may need to be created.

content.justification: Mitigates the risk of 'contamination' by competitor's confidential information, preventing potential misuse or legal issues.

content.implication_supplier: May be required to interact with 'clean teams' if it is a competitor of Zebracorp.
